sp.p: If there were no other Godess of your Sex but she, I should become an Insidel to love, nay an Atheist, believing there were no such De|ity as Love.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Prudence, and Intelligencer her Woman.

sp.speaker: INtelligencer.
sp.p: Madam, all the Town condemns you.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: And do you condemn me too?

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: No, Madam: for I am bound, as being your servant, to submit to your will, liking, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Why, the choise is honest: for they may swear I am not ena|mour'd with his Person: But had he been a fair Youth, or known to be a debanch'd Man, they might have justly condemn'd me, either for my fond Affection and amorous Love, or wilde Choice.

sp.speaker: Intelligencer.
sp.p: 'Faith they may thiak your Choise is wilde, by reason you have chosen out of a Labyrinth, not knowing where his beginning or end is.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Why Virtue is the Beginning, and Happiness, I hope, will be the End.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: I wish it may prove so Madam.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: But pray tell me, Did you ever hear me speak worse than I did to him?

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: How do you mean, Madam, in that you gave your self away?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: No, in that I did not present my self more Eloquently.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: Methought your Speech did not flow so smooth as it was us'd to do, as if your Tongue did know you did commit a fault in granting to his Sute.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: No truly; for my desire did out-run my speech: for desiring to speak best to him I loved most, obstructed my Tongue, which made my words run unevenly.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: That's a common misfortune: for when any one strives to speak wisely, they most often speak foolishly.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: 'Tis true; for strife is an enemy to speech: for those that speak not free and easie, never speak well.
sp.l: For when as Passion wrestles with the Tongue,
The Sense is weak, and down the words are slung,

sp.speaker: 1 GEntleman.
sp.p: 'Tis strange the Lady Prudence, that is so beautiful, rich, and nobly born, and hath so great a wit, should chuse a man so poor and mean, and so ill-favour'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlem.
sp.p: In my opinion it is not strange: for certainly there is a sympathy between the spirits of virtuous souls, which begets love, although in de|formed persons: And this is the true Love; for that which proceeds from Covetousness, or Ambition, or is produced by the Senses, is rather an Ap|petite, which is apt to surfet, or dies as soon as enjoy'd, or turns with For|tunes wheel.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlem.
sp.p: Well, I wish for the Ladies sake, who is known to be Virtu|ous, her Husband may prove as Virtuous as she.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter a Grave Matron, Mistris Fondly, Mistris Vanity, Mistris Trifle, and Mistris Parle?

sp.speaker: MAtron.
sp.p: Ladies, do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: VVhat News?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: VVhy Mistris Simple is gone very early this morning out of Town with Sir Anthony Gosling; and 'tis said they will be maried before they return.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: I cannot believe it: for she was the most unlikely to be maried of any of us all.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I perceive that Maid that can have Fortune to be her friend, shall not want a Husband.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: You say true; and Fortune is a better friend than our Parents are: for our Parents are contented we should live Maids all the time of our lives, when Fortune (most commonly) gives Maids Husbands at one time or other.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Ladies, why do you complain of your Parents for their wary care? who would not have you marry, but to such Husbands as you may be happy withall, and therefore are cautious how to chuse, when Fortune makes Matches at Random.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I had rather marry at Random, than not marry at all.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why then (perchance) in stead of a worthy person, you may marry a base fellow; and in stead of a rich husband, a beggar.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Those women that are curious in their Choise, may chance to die old Maids.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: 'Tis better to die an old Maid, than to live a miserable life, which will be, if an unhappy Wife.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: There is no misery like being an old Maid.
sp.stage: She sings a piece of an old Song

quote.l: O that I were so happy once to be a wedded Wife,
I would fulfil my Husbands will all the days of my life.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p:
I doubt I may sing the Song that says,
O pity take upon me now some gentle Bodie,
And give me the Willow-Branch, for no man will have me.

sp.speaker: Trifle
sp.p: And I may sing this old Song.

quote.l: And no body cares for me:
Although I be but poor and brown,

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And I may sing this old Ballad.

quote.l: Every Bird can choose his Mate,
The Wren can do the same,
The Fish and Fowl their pleasures take,
But I, poor I, poor silly I,
Yea night and day I wear away,

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, Ladies, you are all so desirous to marry, and so impatient because you are not maried, as I doubt when you are maried, your Husbands may sing the Song of Cuckolds all a row.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: It were better for us that our Husbands should be Cuckolds, than we lead Apes in Hell.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter as weeping the Lady Prudence, and her Woman, Intelli|gencer.

sp.speaker: INtelligen.
sp.p: Why do you weep, Madam?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Have I not reason, when one I chose for Honesty proves false, and publickly strives for to disgrace me, by breaking of his Promise, and Ap|pointed day of Mariage?

sp.speaker: Intellig.
sp.p: Perchance he could not come, some Accident hath hinder'd him.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: He might have sent me word the reason of his stay.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: It is likely he is not so rich, as to hire a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: Some would have done it for Charity.

sp.speaker: Intelligen.
sp.p: 'Faith Charity is lazie, and will not go without Reward.

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: If he had loved Me or Honour, he would have found some means or ways.

div.stage: Enter her Servant the Strange Wooer.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: My Virtuous sweet Mistris, what makes such showrs of Tears in Sun-shine Eyes?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: O Sir, I thought you had forsaken me, and left me to the Worlds wilde scorn.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: I should sooner forsake Life, Fame, and Heaven, than forsake you.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: Will you have your Friends to your Wedding, Mistris?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: If you please, Sir: for I am not asham'd of my Choise, nor shall I be asham'd of my Mariage.

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: Nor I, of my self; and for you, the Gods may envy me.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Parle, Mistris Trifle, Mistris Vanity, Mistris Fondly, and a Matron.

sp.speaker: PArle.
sp.p: Shall we go to visit Mistris Simple? she that is now my Lady Gos|ling, and bid her joy.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Yes, if you will: for I long to see how she looks, now she is a Wife.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: So do I, and to see how she behaves her self, since she is maried.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: She is now, Ladies, for the conversation of Wives, and not for the society of Maids; her discourse will be now of Houshold Affairs, as of Houswifry, and of her Husband, and of Children, and hired servants, and not Suters and Courtiers, not Fashions, nor Dressings; neither will she re|turn your Visits: for her Visitings will be to other maried Wives, and her time will be spent at Labours, Christenings, Churchings, and other Matri|monial Gossippings and Meetings.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Howsoever we will go visit her.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I wish we may see her Husband with her, to see if he be kind to her, or not.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: If he be not kind to her, and hath been maried but two or three days, he will never be kind.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: I wonder whether he will kiss her when we are by.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Yes certainly: for new-maried men and their wives take a pleasure to kiss before company.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Hey ho, that maried Wives should have such pleasures, when Maids have none.

div.head: Scene 34.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Letgo, with other Gentlemen.
This Scene of Sir Thomas Letgo, the Lord Marquiss writ.

sp.speaker: LEtgo.
sp.p: O unfortunate villain! that I should be such a Coxcomb, such a Fool, to lose five thousand pounds at Dice! Those bones spotted with the small Pox, the great Pox take them for me, and the Plague to boot: for they have plagued me, and yet I have not a token left about me.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: You may borrow more.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Borrow, you Puppy, you, my land's intail'd, a perpetuity, I have nothing but for life, like a Serving-mans Annuity, or an old Ladies Joynture, no body will lend me any thing; and now I must eat grass and hay: for we are all mortal they say, and they choke me with that. Pox of my Grand|fathers and Fathers provident Wisedomes, with their learned Counsels in the Law; but I hope all their souls fry in Hell for't, that's my com|fort.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard case, that a young Gentleman cannot undoe himself for those Fetters and Bonds of Parchment; truly it is cruel.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I, is it not Iack, to be tied thus, like a dog to a cup-board, and in chains too, that he cannot gnaw or bite them asunder?

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: Faith Sir, 'tis a strange thing, that a man should venture to play his money, whether it should be his or another mans.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: No Dick, you are deceiv'd, I play whether his money should be mine or his. O unfortunate Rogue that I am! and that foolish Star-gazer, the Astrologer, never to see it in my Nativity neither when he cast it! Those Knaves and Fools, to talk of things that they have no guess at what they are, as if the seven Planets, or the twelve Houses, had to do with a cast of Dice, a sine nimble Cheater is worth a thousand of them. Rogue that I am! And now comes in such a consideration into my brain upon my Re|pentance.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: As how pray?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: As how? why if I had this current running money, nay rather, it hath wings, and flies beyond the Fiction of Pegasus: why, if I had it, how I would bestow it for the good of the Common-wealth, as thus: What rich Apparel, with Imbroyderies of gold, and silver, and silk? what Feathers and Mistrisses? what gilt Paris Coaches, Pages, and Lacquies, sa●s number, in rich liveries? what Coachmen, Pos●ilions, with six Flanders Horses, to strike with amazement the whole street as I pass? what running Horses, Hounds, Hawks, Cocks, Greyhounds? what delicious Banquets, Spanish Perfumes, most odoriferous, soft Musick, that should lull the soul asleep, sumptuous Furnitures, so as I would surfet the Senses, and make the seven Deadly Sins live like Princes?
sp.l: And set up Sin and Vanity to the hight,
Since those are still the Gentlemens delight.
sp.p: But O my money is gone, which cuts off all my hopes of exercising all those virtuous ways! well, let me cogitate, and boy, give me a melancholy Pipe to cloud all hopes of joys with sadder thoughts.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Truly 'tis pity he hath lost his money: for you hear how Religi|ously he would have spent it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Most like a Gentleman, I must needs say that for him.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.p: Most piously indeed; but prethee let us walk for a while, lest we should disturb his Thoughts: no more Discourse, but let us tie our Tongues.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Content, till his be loose.

div.stage: They sit mute a time, while he sits musing.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What Contemplation now?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Pious and charitable ones. But this damn'd money, this runnagado, this vagabond money!

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But if you had a statute to whip her home to her own Parish, it would do well.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I Iack, but there is no such law, the more the pity; but this abo|minable money disorders all the World. What work makes it betwixt Pa|rents and Children, Husbands and Wives, Brothers and Sisters, Masters and Servants, Landlords and Tenants, Citizens and their Prentices, Mistrisses and their Maids, and between Kings and their subject? Corrupts all the World, breaks Friendship, betrays Friends, raises Rebellions, commits Treason, and corrupts Virgins: It is the Pander and Bawd to all business; the States-man is fed by this damn'd Lady Pecunia, the Lawyer serves her, the Merchants her slave, the Shop-keeper her vassal, and the Countryman her Tenant, Lords and Ladies her pensioners, and greatest Monarchs pay tribute to her; the Logician argues for her, the Orator pleads for her, and many Ecclesiasticals preach for her, the Vicar General and his Conclave are rul'd by her, and the poor Poet, she draws his copperas from his ink, and makes him flatter her. This horrid Lady Sorceress, so to bewitch the World! Is there no law a|gainst this Enchantress, that thus doth still abuse the World, and all that's in it? The very Souldiers sword is charmed by her, and all his guns are si|lent at her presence. This she-devil!

sp.speaker: 3 Gentlem.
sp.p: But I would you had your she-devil again for all that: But what Pious and Charitable Consideration had you, if you had your money again?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Marry Sir, First I would build an Hospital for decay'd Ladies that were maim'd in Venus's wars, losing a nose, or so, never yet any care taken of them, the more is the pity.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Very good: and what next?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Next I would buy such a piece of ground, and build a Bedlam, and then put in all such Divines as preach themselvs out of their power and riches; and I would put all such Lawyers in, as pleaded themselves out of pra|ctice; and all such Citizens as petition'd themselves out of trade.

sp.speaker: 3 Gentlem.
sp.p: These are good and pious Acts: But would not you provide a place or means for such as were undone by playing at Dice and Cards, and the like.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: No, they should have only Fools Coats to be known by, and I would be the Master of them.
sp.stage: Here ends my Lord Marquiss of Newcastles Writing

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Parle, Mistris Trifle, Mistris Vanity, Mistris Fondly, and a Matron, to the Lady Gosling: These all bid her Ioy; She thanks them in a low Voice, and a constrain'd and for|mal Behaviour, and a foolish grave Countenance.

sp.speaker: TRifle.
sp.p: How doth your Husband, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Gosling.
sp.p: I hope he's well, he's gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You look pale since you were maried.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I was not very well this morning: for I could not eat my Break|fast; truly I have lost my stomack since I have been maried.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Perchance you are breeding.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Oh sie, no surely; but yet my Maid laughs, and tells me I am.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I hope, Lady, you are not breeding already? for you have not been maried above three days.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I have heard that some have been with Child as soon as they were maried; and my Maid told me she served a Mistris, who, the next day she was maried was with Child.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: By my Faith that was very soon.

div.stage: The Lady Gosling pulls off her Glove to take her Hand|kerchief, a pretence to shew her Wedding-ring.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Me thinks it is strange to see you have a Wedding-ring on your Thumb.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: You will come to wear a Wedding-ring on your Thumb one of these days.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: What is the Posie?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I like too well to change.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis well you do: for if you did not, you could hardly change, un|less your Husband dies.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Heaven forbid: for I would not have him die for all the World; for he is one of the lovingest and fondest Husbands that ever was.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: The first Moneth is a fond Moneth, Lady.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: And are you fond of him?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Yes truly: for I hang about his neck when he is at home.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But you will weary your Husband, Lady, if you hang a long time.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I would very sain you did see my Husband.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: We much desire so to do.

div.stage: She calls her Maid Joan: The Maid an|swers as within, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: Is your Master, Sir Anthony Gossing, come home yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: In truth he is too blame to stay out so long, knowing I am not well when he is away.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Are you sick in his absence?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I am best pleas'd when he is with me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: New-maried Wives are always so; but after they have been maried some time, they are worst pleased when their Husbands are with them.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Prudence as a Bride that's very finely drest in glori|ous Apparel, her Brdegroom in poor old cloaths: He leads her as to the Church, limping with his Wooden Leg. The Bridal Guests seem to make signs of scorning as they follow.
They all go out but two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntlem.
sp.p: Me thinks it is a strange sight to see such a Bride, and such a Bridegroom. I do imagine them to be like Pluto and Proserpine.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Nay rather, they are like Venus and Vulcan.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But she is too chaste to entertain a Mars to Cuckold him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: It is to be hop'd she will take her liberty with variety: for extra|vagant love is seldom constant.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: If that rule prove true, he may be a Cuckold indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis likely he will: for women chuse to marry such deformed men a purpose; first to excuse their fault, thinking the World will never con|demn them, their Husbands being ill-favour'dly mis-shapen, or thinking their Husbands will be well content, knowing their own infirmities, to be a sharer.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But I wonder she did not new-cloath him: for though he is not so rich to buy himself a Wedding-Suit, yet she hath means enough to buy him many several suits, and rich.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: There was no time to make him Wedding-cloaths, because he came not till his Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Well, let us go see them maried, and wish them joy.

div.head: Scene 37
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Letgo, Sir William Holdfast, and two or three other Gentlemen.
So far of this Scene as Sir Thomas Letgo's, the Marquis of Newcastle writ.

sp.speaker: LEtgo.
sp.p: Since my losses, I have such a desire of Revenge, as my fingers itch to be at it, and the Palsie is in my eldow with the imagination of throw|ing those partial bones, call'd by the Vulgar, Dice; they say they are square fellows, but I doubt it: Well, have at them, whatsoever comes on't; for I long more for them, than the great Belly that long'd to bite her Husbands Nose, or to give him a box on the Ear; or she that threw her loas into a barrel of Tar; and if I have not my longings, in my Conscience I shall mis|carry.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Take heed Sir, that you do not miscarry, if you have the Dice.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: How can he do that? for he hath nothing to miscarry withall, not a farthing, his pockets swell not; 'tis but an imaginary Child, a windy or watry Mole, or a Moon-calf; he needs no Dice to be his Midwife for the La|dy Pecunia, a meer Timpany of the Fancy, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: O Iack, thou art cruel! there is nothing so horrid as truth to a Gen|tleman, and such truths too. I know not what to do with my self: for I can|not be alone, those are such foolish fellows that have parts, as they call them, and I hate both them and their parts.
sp.stage: Enters the Lady Mute as passing.
sp.p: Look here is my foolish Mistris, by the Gods I'll play her, I'll set her you, Sir William Holdfast, what will you stake against her?

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Sir, a Lady, and such a Lady, is beyond price unvaluable.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Come, come, leave your Courtship to Ladies, and throw, and have at her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Why Sir, with the Ladies leave, I will set you five thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Five thousand pound? why she hath two thousand pound land a year man, and is an Heir.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: But I consider a Wife is chargeable: for I shall maintain her ac|cording to her Birth, and my own Honour; besides, children will come on, and they are chargeable.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: For her charge, I will maintain her as cheap as a Changeling, a Dairy-maid, or a Kitchin-wench: why, she is a fool, and for children, you will not have them the first day certainly; but her Estate will maintain her, and make thee rich; besides, a witty Wife is a curse, and a fool but a Trouble.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: But I consider there are two Joyntures goe out of her Estate.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: VVhy, they are so old, they will both pick over the Pearch the next Fall, and die of the Frownsies; or if not, I will present thee with a little Rats|banc for them, to put in their Caudles.

sp.speaker: Holdstast.
sp.p: VVell Sir, I honour the Lady so much, as I will set ten thousand pound against her.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: By the Gods, make it but fifreen thousand, and here I set her.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Content, and we will take one anothers words, and these Noble Gentlemen shall be the witnesses.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: VVith all my Soul. Give me the Dice, they that throw most at three throws with three dice, let them win: for three is the Ladies number But first let me invoke them.
sp.l: Thou Lady Fortune, here I do implore thee,
Now metamorphos'd into Dice that's three
My better Fate with Sixes to be crown'd,
Thy Favourite winning fifteen thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Throw Sir, without any more Invocation of this various Godess.

div.stage: Sir Thomas Letgo takes the Lady Mute by the hand, and sets her close to the Table they play on.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Come, you Fool, stand here on my side, and now have at your mo|ney Sir. Two fives and a six? 'tis well; again, two fixes and a five? I thank thee Lady Fortune, if I win, thou shalt never be call'd a whore again, but a virtuous and pious Lady; once again, three sixes? Sweet Lady Fortune, how have they wronged thee heretofore, in laying their own follies to thy charge! Malicious lying Detractors, that defame Ladies thus.
sp.l: Here take the Dice, which are so square and new,
And bid your fifteen thousand pound adieu.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: You will give me leave to throw Sir (Throws) what is that, three sixes?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Well, again.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Three sixes again? I vow I believe she is a Virtuous Lady in|deed.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: I cannot tell yet, I will not take upon me for the noblest Lady in the World, throw again, and I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Why then have at your Mistris; three sixes again? O Virtuous Lady Fortune!

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: By the Gods, Iack, the Lady Fortune is a whore, a pocky whore.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why did you meddle with her then? I knew you would get a Clap.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Nay I have got two; but now I shall have a strict Diet that will cure me.

div.stage: Here ends my Lord Marquisses writing.
When Holdfast hath won, he speaks to the Lady Mute.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Are you pleased with my Fortune?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: It is an injury to Nature to whisper out your words, but rather they should be blown abroad by Fames loud Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Had I Rhetorick, as I have none, the loudness of the voice would take away the Elegance of the Speech, and drown the sense of the Subject: But I desire you, and all the rest of this Company may know, I am so well pleased with the Change, as for this Act of Fortunes savour, I shall become a Votress to Her Deity, for whom I will build an Altar more famous than Mausolus's Tomb; it shall be built with Rhetorick, polished with Eloquence, carved with Allegories, pensil'd with Fancies, and gilded with Praise; the Materials shall be wise Brains, honest Hearts, and eloquent Tongues; on this Altar shall burn the Fire of Life, and all the Actions of Industry shall be of|fered thereon.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: What, can you speak?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I am not dumb, although my name is Mute.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You were almost as silent as if you were dumb, all the time you were mine.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but now I am set at liberty, my Tongue can run freely.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Why, you are as much bound to him now, as you were to me before.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I account this bondage a freedom: for none can be a slave that is bound to a worthy person, who hath a noble nature.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Pray Sir Thomas Letgo do not Court my fortunate Mistris: for though you thought her a fool, I know her to be both wise, and also to have a great Wit.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: I fear my wit is but an Infant-wit, and lies in swathling-clouts a|sleep in the cradle of obscurity: But Time may give it growth, and practice strength, and experience may bring it into the light of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: If you had no Affection for me, yet you might have had so much civility, as to have exprest your self sociable.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: Civility doth not bind any one to divulge their own infirmities, as to express their ignorance by their discourse; besides, for my part, I was so bashful and fearful, lest I should cause errours, and make such defects as were not naturally in me, but only produced by innocent ignorance, which made me choose silence to shun scorns; but I found it was not a sufficient defence.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Liberty, and the other Ladies. One of the Gentlemen speaks to them.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Here is a Miracle, not only that the dumb speaks, but she that was thought a natural Fool, proves a great Wit.

div.stage: All the Ladies laugh, and repeat scornfully, a wit, a wit.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: That word, Wit, that those Ladies return in scorn, I with Industry will make it like a reflection, to cause a double light, and give a greater heat of Sense, Reason, and Judgment, Fancy and Phrase.
sp.stage: Then she speaks to Sir William Holdfast.
sp.p: Sir, if I behave my self indiscreetly, impute it to an over-flowing joy; and those follies I commit, are not by Nature born, nor yet by Education bred in me.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p:
Sweet Mistris, you can no more be guilty of a fault, than Angels
in Ioves Mansion. Fare you well, Sir Thomas Letgo, the Lady Liberty will counterpoize your losses.

div.stage: Sir William Holdfast goes out, leacting forth his Mi|stris the Lady Mute, whereat Sir Thomas Letgo frowns.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Let her go, Sir Thomas Letgo: for if she be not a Fool, for cer|tain she is wanton, or otherwise she would not be so well pleas'd with change.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: He hath affronted me.

div.stage: Sir Thomas goes out frowning. The company speak to the Lady Liberty.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: There is no change so visible, as the most opposite: but Sir Tho|mas Letgo is both troubled and angry: wherefore Lady Liberty, you had best try to pacifie him.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: He is like little children, which despise what they have, but cry when they are taken from them.

div.head: Scene 38.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Parle, Mistris Trifle, Mistris Vanity, and a Matron.

sp.speaker: PArle.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, prethee teach me something to keep in laughter, or I shall disgrace my self for ever.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Are you so loosly set together, that you cannot hold?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No, I shall burst out laughter at this ridiculous Wedding, before all the Bridal Company, and so be thought rude.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: If you burst out nothing else, the company will excuse you: for Weddings are compos'd of mirth and jollity, and every one hath liberty and leave to sport and play, to dance and skip about.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: But if the Bridegroom limping should come to take me out to dance, I shall laugh in his face, which he will take as an Affront, and then will kick me with his wooden stump.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: O no, he seems too wise to take Exception, and too civil to kick a Lady; he will rather kiss you, than kick you.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I had rather he should kick me thrice, than kiss me once, by Iupiter. I would not be his Bride, to be the Empress of the whole World.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: It is probable, nor he your Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Come away, the Bride is going to bed, and you stand talking here?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p:
To bed, say you? If I were she, I would first choose to go to my
Grave. Hymen and Cupid bless me from such a bed-fellow as the Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Prethee let us watch, to see if we can descry whether he hath clo|ven feet or not?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Should he have no Cloven Feet, yet certainly the Original of his shape came from Hell: for surely he was begot by the Devil, on some witch or another, and his Cloaths were spun by the Devils Dam.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: The truth is, he hath damnable old cloaths on, they seem as if they were made of old rags, scrap'd out of dunghils.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I perceive, Ladies, you prefer Beauty and Cloaths, before Vir|tue and Merit.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Faith Virtue is too rigid to be belov'd, and Merit is but an incor|poreal Spirit, and an incorporeal Spirit is no good bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Wherefore I would have a Handsome, Personable, Fashionable, Courtly man.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Nay, if I could have my wish, I would wish for more than one man.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: The truth is, that one man would have too much by either of those Ladies.

div.head: Scene 39.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Letgo, and the Lady Liberty.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Was it not enough to win, but to affront me with my losses?

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: Its true; they say Losers have only leave to speak, but Winners may be merry.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Was there no subject for his mirth but I?

div.stage: Enter Sir William Holdfast, and his Mistris, the Lady Mute.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You are a false cheating fellow.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: You are a base lying Villain, for saying so.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You have cozen'd me of my Mistris, and I will have her again.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: I have won her saitly and honestly, and I will keep her with my Life.

div.stage: They both draw and fight. Mute runs to Sir William Holdfast, and cries out.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: For Heaven-sake leave off to sight for me, I am not worth the life you hazard for me.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Sweet Mistris, fear not, Death hath no power on me, so long as you stand by.

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: O let my sad complaints, like murmuring Rivers, flow thorough your Ears, that running into your Heart, may move it to a gentle pity.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: You should have let them fight, to see whether Portune hath the same power on their Swords, as she hath on the Dice? whether she can dis|pose of Life and Death, as of Honour and Riches?

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: You may part us now, but we shall meet again.

div.stage: Sir Thomas and the company go out, only Sir William and the Lady Mute stays. The Lady Mute weeps.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: My dear Mistris, what makes your eyes to flow?

sp.speaker: Mute.
sp.p: As my tears flow thorough my eyes, so I wish my life may flow thorough my tears, then might you live in safety.

sp.speaker: Holdfast.
sp.p: Let not your love to me make waste of such Tears, that every drop might save a Life, nay save a Soul, they are so pure and penetrating. But your fears doe apprehend my Foe more dangerous than he is.

div.head: Scene 40.
div.stage: A Bed is thrust on the Stage, as presenting the Bride-chamber, the Bride being in the Bed finely drest, and a company of young Ladies her Companions about her.

sp.speaker: TRifle.
sp.p: 'Faith confess to us your Maiden-companions, do not you repent?

sp.speaker: Prudence.
sp.p: So fat am I from repentance, as I should repent, were I not as now I am.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: You will repent before seven years.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Seven years? you mean seven days: for seven years to our Sex, is se|ven Ages; for Maids and Widows account it so before their mariage, and maried Wives do account time so until their Husbands die.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: 'Faith I think there are few women, but when they marry, hope to be Widows.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's certain; and were it not for such hopes, men would hardly get Wives.

stage.hi: Enter the Bridegroom, and a company of Gentlemen and Knights; then enters a ser|vant with a rich night-gown or Mantle, another servant with a rich Cap, Waste|coat, and Slippers: Then the Bridegroom first pulls off his patch from his Eye, then pulls off his bumbast Doublet, and then his wooden Leg, and his snarled Periwig, having a sine head of hair of his own; then puts on his wastcoat, cap, slippers, and night-gown, he then appearing very handsome, the company staring upon him, the mean time they as in amazement, He speaks to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom.
sp.p: Fair Ladies, as other men strive to adorn themselves, to mend their broken Bodies, and patch up their decays with false and feigned shews, to cozen credulous women, that think them such as they appear, when they abuse your sweet & gentle natures: But lest my Wife should think me better than I am, or expect more than I could give her, I formed my self far worse than Nature made me; nor have I promised more than well I can perform.
sp.l: And if she lov'd me crooked, lame, and blind,
Now I am perfect, she'll not be less kind.

div.stage: The Bed drawn off, the Bridegroom follows, the men go out with him as in a maze, only Mistris Trifle, Va|nity, and Parle slays.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Heyday, Riddle me, riddle me, what's this? A man blind, and not blind, lame, and not lame, crooked, and not crooked, ill-favour'd, and handsome.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: 'Faith it is like the Tale of the great Bear of warwick.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: What Tale was that?

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Why of a King that had three Daughters, and when they were of mariageable years, the King their Father ask'd them whether they had ra|ther to have a Husband that were a man a days, and a beast at nights, or a Husband that was a beast at days, and a man at nights? and if they would marry, they must choose one of those that were sometimes men, and some|times beasts, or otherwise they must never marry; but they, rather than to live old Maids, were resolved to marry, were their Husbands at all times beasts: so the two eldest chose to have their Husbands men a days, and beasts at nights; for, said they, we can conceal their beastliness at nights, but not a days, for the light will divulge them to the publick view of the World; but the youngest chose a Husband, one that was a beast a days, and a man at nights: for, said she, I will please my self, not caring what the World thinks or says: for I am sure, said she, the World cares not what I think or say; whereupon they were all three maried, and the youngest Ladies Husband was a great Bear a days, but a very handsome man at nights.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: O that every woman were so well match'd! for then they would be always pleased, and never jealous: for in the day-time, when men doe Court and plead Loves Sute, and point out private meetings,
sp.l: They have no words to wooe, nor persons for to win,
And in the night their Wives their Arms do circle in.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: But say your Husband the He-bear, should meet a Mistris She-bear, I believe you would be jealous then.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I confess I should be somewhat lumpish.

div.stage: Enter Mistris Fondly, and a Matron.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Hey, ho!

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: VVhat is the cause you sigh?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Nature never made so handsome a man as the Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: And you sigh because you are not the Bride.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: 'Faith the Devil tempts me to break a Commandement.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: VVhat Commandement?

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: To covet my Neighbours goods.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Why he is no part of your Neighbours goods, unless he be a good man.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Well, he is a goodly man, and whether he is a man that is good, I cannot tell: But howsoever I will never trust the outside more, I will never believe a patch'd eye is blind, nor a bunch'd back is crooked, nor a wooden leg lame, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: And if you will not believe it whilst you live, when you are dead, I doubt you will forget it; but howsoever the Devil tempts me as much as you to covet him that's none of mine.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray Ladies give me leave to remember you, in that you said you would not be his Bride, were it the way to make you Empress of the whole World.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but then we were blind of one eye as he was; but now we see with both our eyes as he doth.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Come, let us go into the Bride-chamber, and out-dare his beauty on the forfeiture of our hearts.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: You need not go to seek Love: for he will catch you, although you run away.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And you will catch Love, if with the Bridegroom stay.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: I doubt that.

div.head: Scene 41.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Letgo, and the Lady Liberty.

sp.speaker: LIberty.
sp.p: Let me perswade you to be friends: for if you seem to mourn for that which you made slight of, and to quarrel unjustly, and sight for for that you cannot have, nor is not rightly yours, you will be thought im|prudent, shunn'd as a wrangling Gamester, and accounted a Ranting Di|sturber, and laught at for a fool, for setting such a Mistris at a stake you thought too much to lose; but if you will save your Reputation, you must seem to rejoyce you are quit of her.

sp.speaker: Letgo.
sp.p: Well, I will take your counsel; and I have this satisfaction, That I am not the first man that hath been deceiv'd by Women, nor shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p:
That's true; and so generally it is known, as 'tis become an or|dinary saying, and the saying will be made good as long as mankind lasts: for
though men may dissemble to women, yet it is women that deceive men, and we glory in it.

sp.speaker: 1 GEnt.
sp.p: Do you hear the News?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What News?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why the Bridegroom is prov'd to be the Great Duke of Gran|dy's Son.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why you have heard that the old Prince of Grandy had two Sons, and the younger Son would not be perswaded from going to Travel, and it was reported he was drownd in a Voyage by Sea, for which his Father mourn'd a long time, as loving him extremely; and you know, to add to his afflictions, his Eldest Son dies, so as he became as childless, until this time that his Son is returned safe, for which he is the most joy'd man that e|ver was, and is so fond of the Prince his Son, as he continually imbraces and kisses him, and hangs about his neck like a fond Bride.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Why did he come so privately, and in a disguise?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: As for his private comming home, the reason was, That having oftentimes ask'd the Magor, to return into his own Country, and being as of|ten deny'd, and at last threaten'd to be destroy'd if he should offer to go a|way, and quit the Magor's Service: for this Prince was General of all his Forces, and was the man that the Merchants cry'd up to be another Iulius Caesar, although they knew not of what birth or quality he was of; but to get away, he was forc'd to steal away in a disguise, in which disguise he wooed and won his Lady, the now Princess: for whilst he lay privately in the City, until such time as he could hansomly & conveniently discover him|self, he hearing the talk of the Publick Wooing, and also of the Virtue, Beau|ty, and Wit of the young Lady, went to hear and to see her, whom he no sooner heard and saw, and being taken with her good Fame, honouring her Virtue, admiring her Beauty, and being extremely delighted with her Wit, became a Lover, and also a VVooer; but for the better trial of her Virtue, he wooed her in his disguised, deformed shape, and unknown quality, left his Dignity and VVealth might have inticed her Ambition, and not his Merit, to have won her Love, or his Person might have catch'd her Eye, but not his Love her Heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: The Gods are just, rewarding in the end the good intentions with good success, and Virtue with felicity.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter the Bridegroom according to his Dignity, as being a Prince, richly cloathed, and honourably attended with Gentlemen with their hats off, he leading in the Bride his Princess, and a great many Ladies waiting on her: The Prince and Princess sit in two Chairs, and the rest of the company on each side of them to see an Anti mask presented to them. When the Antick-maskers had dan|ced, a Song was sung.
These Songs following the Lord Marquiss writ.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: VErtue and Honour you did take,
And Beauty scorn'd as vading;
Thus you a Godess it doth make,
'Rove mortal Ladies trading.
They love the Body, you the Soul,
They Shape, but you the Mind,
Your Love those grosser loves controll,
Which shews their Love is blind.
His wooden Leg is thrown away,
The black Patch for the blind,
The Bunch on's back asswag'd to day,
As hansome as his Mind.
This now is your reward, Sweet Madam,
The Gods they are not lath
To give you one, handsome as Adam,
And thus enjoy them both.

div.stage: Then the Maskers dance again, and after their Dance another Song.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Loves Miracles not ceased be,
The Lame to walk, the Blind to see,
The Crooked is made straight, 'tis true,
And these Loves Wonders made by you.
His Body metamorphos'd is,
By your Ambrosia sweeter kiss;
Such power hath Love when you do sip
The Gods pure Nectar from your Lip.
All Ioys attend you night and day,
Be each to other fresh as May,
Renewing pleasures everyhower,
And sweeter than the sweetest Flower.

div.stage: The Maskers dance again, and after, another Song.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Envious Ladies now repine,
Since you are crost,
In having lost
A Prince so handsome and so fine.
Mourn in black patches for your sins,
Despair each Curl,
And every Purl,
And throw away your dressing-pins.
Lay by your richer Gowns of State,
For now you'l faint,
For all your paint,
When 'think of your unhappier Fate.
For these Love-pitfals they are stale,
And all despise
Your glancing Eyes,
For all forc'd Arts in Love they'l fail.
Now let your specious gliding pass,
Or your Lips fed
With biting red,
Despair, and break each Looking-glass.

div.stage: Here ends my Lord Marquis his writing.

Then the Maskers dance again, and so goe out, the Prince and Princess, and the Company goes out all but a Ma|tron and some young Ladies, who stay, and look upon each other very sadly, without speaking to each other.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What, Ladies, are you Thunder-struck with the Princes Honour, or are you blasted with the Lightning of his Splendor, or crush'd with the wheel of her good Fortune?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, how blindly Fortune throws her gifts away!

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: One would think she had clear Eyes, when she bestow'd her Fa|vours upon the Princess.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: She is become so proud, since she is become a Princess, as she will not look on us that were her companions; and she thinks scorn to speak to us: for she said not one word to any of us.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: She had no occasion to speak to you; but I am confident, If you speak to her, you will find her as civil and obliging, as ever she was.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: 'Faith we care not: for we can live without being oblig'd to her.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: They are not the happiest that have the greatest Titles.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Pride will have a Fall.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I perceive it is hand to get the good opinion of the World: for you rail'd at her Course, laugh'd at her Choise, condemn'd her Mariage, and now you envy her good Success.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: We envy her? you are mistaken: for she must be of greater va|lue, and we less worthy than we are, to raise an Envy.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Nay Ladies, if you are angry, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Then we shall be rid of a pratling fool.

div.stage: Enter three or four old Ladies, the Mothers to the young Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1 Old Lady.
sp.p: O, wisedome in youth is a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 Old Lady.
sp.p: Happy is that Parent that hath a discreet Child.

sp.speaker: 3 Old Lady.
sp.p: Such Children give their Parents Honour in their Graves.

sp.speaker: 4 Old Lady.
sp.p: Pray let us Petition that a Law may be Enacted for this Pub|lick Wooing.

sp.speaker: 1 Old Lady.
sp.p: We shall not need to Petition: for the Princess, I dare war|rant you, will get the Prince to Enact a Law for this Publick Wooing for her Fame, she being the only first that hath been wooed so.

sp.speaker: Old Ladies.
sp.p: Well, Daughters, make her your Pattern.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Yesterday, that was the Wedding-day, my Parents did condemn the Bride, calling her Fool, and saying she was mad, and forbid me to imi|tate her.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: 'Tis no wonder our Natures are so various, when as our Educati|on are so inconstant: for we are instructed to imitate Fortune, which is to be restless, and to spoil that good we have done.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Or to better the worse.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No 'faith: for I perceive Fortune hath more power to do hurt than good; for Fortune ruines, or at least disturbs Virtuous Acts, and frustrates Wisedom's Counsels.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Ladies, the Princess desires your company to dance.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Pray excuse me Sir: for I have so great a pain on my left side, as I can hardly fetch my breath.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: And I have such a pain in my head, as I date not dance, for fear it should ake more.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: And truly I have so streight a shooe, as it is a pain for me to tread a step.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: And I am not well in my stomach: wherefore excuse us Sir to the Princess.

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Parrot, and the Lady Minion, and the La|dy Gosling.

sp.speaker: PArrot.
sp.p: God give you Joy, I have not seen you since you were maried.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: You are welcome into the maried Society.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: I thank you Madam. Truly I am so tyr'd.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: With what, Madam?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: With helping my Neighbour the Lady Breeder to hold her back.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: VVhy, is she in Labour?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: She is brought to Bed; but on my word she hath had a hard bar|gain: for she hath had a sore Labour.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: VVhat hath God sent her?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: A lusty boy. Indeed it is one of the goodliest children that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: But how chance she did not send for me to her Labour?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: She came on such a sudden, as she had hardly Time to send for the Midwife; but she was mightily troubled you were not there, she doubts you will take it ill.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: We have reason: for if we could not have come time enough to her Labour, we might have come time enough to the cup of Rejoycing.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: But she will bid you to the Christening.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: That's some amends: But this hard labour of the Lady Breeders will fright you.

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: No: for I have as much courage as other maried Wives have, though truly, Sir Anthony Gosling, my Husband, was very loth I should goe: for (said he to me) prethee sweet Duck do not go: I answer'd and said to him, my hony-love I must go, for it is the part of one wife to help another; besides, a gossipping company doth help to ease the womens pains; and if I go not to their Labour, they will not come to mine.

sp.speaker: Minion.
sp.p: Why, are you with Child?

sp.speaker: Gosling.
sp.p: No, but I hope I shall be shortly.

sp.speaker: Parrot.
sp.p: Come, we will go and chide your Husband, that he hath been ma|ried a week, and his Wife not with child.

sp.speaker: Lady Gosling.
sp.p: Yes, pray goe chide him, and I will bear your company.

sp.speaker: PRincess.
sp.p: Sir, pray perswade the unmaried Ladies to dance: for I can|not intreat them.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: That's strange: for Ladies will dance without intreating; for no intreating will make them sit still.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: It seems they are not in their dancing-humour to day: for every one finds some excuse for to deny.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Let them alone, and take no notice of their reserved humours, and they will dance without intreating; nay, they will intreat you they may dance.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: If it please your Highness, the Ladies desire you would give them leave to Celebrate your Mariage with their Mirth, and to express their Joy with their Dancing.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: We shall take it as a Favour to our Nuptials.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Did not I tell you they would desire to dance?

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Truly I was so ignorant, as I knew not so much the nature of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You knew not so much of their follies.

div.head: Scene 46.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Parle, Mistris Fondly. Mistris Trifle, Mistris Vanity.

sp.speaker: VAnity.
sp.p: Let us strive to make the Bride jealous.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: That's impossible now; but you may not work to good effect some a half a year hence.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Why I have known a Bridegroom leer her the next day he was ma|ried.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: Perchance a Bridegroom may: for men are sooner cloy'd than women; but a Bride will fondly hang about her Husbands neck a week at least.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: A week? nay a moneth: for a woman is fond the first moneth, sick the second moneth, peevish the third moneth, coy the fourth moneth, false the fifth moneth, and Cuckolds her Husband the sixth moneth.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: Then a maried man sprouts Horns in half a year.

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: Yes: for they are set the day of his mariage, and some half a year after they are budded, but not so fully grown as to appear to the pub|lick view.

sp.speaker: Trifle.
sp.p: But will nothing hinder the growth?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: No 'faith, but Death; and Death, like a Frost, doth nip those ten|der buds.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Which death, the mans, or the womans?

sp.speaker: Parle.
sp.p: The womans: for if the man dies, and his Widow marries again, the dead Husband is horn'd in his Grave, and the living Husband is horn'd in his Bed.

sp.speaker: Vanity.
sp.p: Then their Horns may be put together, as Stags in Rutting|time.

sp.speaker: Fondly.
sp.p: I had rather make Horns, than talk of Horns; therefore I'll go dance.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntlem.
sp.p: Where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: At Church.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Did a sit of Devotion hurry you to the Church to pray?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: No 'faith, I went not to pray, but to joyn a pair of Lovers hands in Wedlocks Bonds: for they chose me to be their Father, to give them in the Church.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What Lovers were they, that were so foolish to marry?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: So honest, you mean.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: There is more folly in't than honesty, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Thou art an Infidel, nay a very Athiest.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I am a Naturalist. But who are they that are maried?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Why Sir William Holdfast and the Lady Mute.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: The truth is, he is a worthy Person, and she is a virtuous and sweet Lady: wherefore they deserve each other; besides, she is an Heir, and he hath a great Estate.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: He hath so.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What, is the Wedding kept private?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Yes, there are only two or three Friends; but I must goe dine with them, therefore fare thee well, unless you will go with me: for you know you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I know I shall, therefore I shall go with you.

div.head: Scene 48.
div.stage: Enter the Prince and Princess, and all the Ladies and Gallants, as Knights and Gentlemen: They dance upon the Stage, and then go out.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: OUr Auth'ress here hath sent me for her pay,
She's at the Charge of Wit to make the Play;
But if you think it not worthy of Praise,
Nor an Applause of Hands, her Fame to raise,
She doth desire that it in pawn may lie,
Till redeem'd by a better Comedie.
